ParentCompanyName: Maryland and Virginia Milk Producers Co-op

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMARY
Executive Summary for Marva Maid Dairy

1.0 RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE
POLICIES

Marva Maid Dairy is concerned with the safety and well-being of its
employees as well as its neighbors and the environment. It is the policy of
Marva Maid Dairy to operate its facility in a manner that will minimize the
risk of any accidental release. While not all accidents are preventable, it is
the policy of Marva Maid Dairy to take all appropriate steps to minimize the
possibility and impact of such accidents and releases. These steps include
the proper training of our operators, development of safety programs and
operating procedures and frequent review and refresher training.
Since Marva Maid Dairy recognizes that there are accidents that may occur
regardless of the amount of training, planning and program development it
is also the policy of Marva Maid Dairy to be prepared for any possible
contingency. Toward this end Marva Maid Dairy has developed an
emergency response plan. The local emergency response first response
agency as well as the Local Emergency Planning Committee has been
involved in ongoing discussion and coordination of this emergency
response plan.

2.0 PROCESS DESCRIPTION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Covered Process:

The covered process is an ammonia refrigeration system serving a dairy
facility providing
storage for milk and other dairy products. The refrigeration system has a
published
charge of 19,750 pounds of Anhydrous. The refrigeration process can be
divided into two primary missions:

1. Maintain storage and production areas at approximately 34Â°F to 40Â°F to
preserve quality and freshness of the product.

2. Maintain water at approximately 32Â°F for use in the various production
processes.

Compressors:

The system has 7 compressors operating as a single stage system. The
system is designed
at 78Â°F wet bulb and 34 PSIG suction pressure. The screw compressors all
utilize liquid injection oil cooling. All compressors are stage

d utilizing a new
microcontroller system.

Condensers:

The system has 3 evaporative condensers. The system has a Hansen
Technologies refrigerated Auto-purger to insure the removal of air or other
non-condensables and utilizes a treatment system to control algae,
bacteria, fungus and scaling.

Receivers / Vessels:

The system has one high pressure receiver and one critical receiver to
insure oil cooling for the screw compressors as well as one large recirculating
receiver.

Evaporators / Chillers:

The system utilizes some 15 pump overfed evaporators to provide climate
control for the entire processing and storage facility. Additionally, there are 2 flooded
chillers providing chilled water for the processing areas. 

3.0 WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

As part of the Marva Maid Dairy safety program a Process Hazard
Assessment was completed. As part of this assessment one worst case
and one alternate case release scenario was completed. RMP*Comp was
used to calculate the distance to the toxic endpoint for each of these
scenarios. The impact of this release scenario was assessed using a plot of
the resulting distance, developed using Marplot, Landview 6 and the 2000
Census data.

3.1 Worst-Case Scenario Description

One worst case release scenario was developed based on a release of
5,579 pounds of ammonia from the high pressure receiver. This represents
the maximum planned contents of the largest receiver as specified in 40
CFR 68.25(b)(1). The scenario was calculated using RMP-Comp and was
based on the entire contents being released as a vapor over a ten-minute
period resulting in a release rate of 558 pounds per minute. No mitigating
measures were included in the calculation. Additional criteria for the
calculation were:

Topography: Urban surroundings

Toxic Endpoint: 0.14 mg/L; basis: ERPG-2

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint: .9 miles (2.1 kilometers)

The following assumptions were made in calculating this scenario:

Wind Speed: 1.5 meters/seco

nd (3.4 miles/hour)
Stability Class: F
Air Temperature: 77 degrees F (25 degrees C)

It was determined that a release of this nature under these conditions
would affect approximately 4,067 housing units and a total population of
8,932 people.

3.2 Alternative Release Scenario Description

One alternate case release scenario, as described and specified in 40 CFR
68.28, was developed. The rational of this scenario is based on an actual
event at the facility. The quantity released from a 3/4 ammonia liquid line
struck with a forklift resulted in a release estimated to be 1,330 pounds of
ammonia. The scenario was calculated using RMP-Comp and was based
on the actual observed events. An automatic control system which
isolated the leaking section is a mitigating measure attributed with
maintaining the minimal release quantity. Additional criteria for the
calculation were:

Condensing Pressure: 155 psia
Tank Temp: 81Â°F
Release Rate: 1,330 pounds per min
Mitigation Measures: Automatic isolation control system.
Topography: Urban surroundings
Toxic Endpoint: 0.14 mg/L; basis: ERPG-2
Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint: 0.2 miles (0.3 kilometers)
Wind Speed: 3 meters/second (6.7 miles/hour)
Stability Class: D
Air Temperature: 77Â° F (25 degrees C)

It was determined that a release of this nature under these conditions
would have minimal effect offsite.

4.0 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND
CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

In an effort to insure the general safety and well-being of plant personnel as
well as the community Marva Maid Dairy has implemented numerous
safety and emergency preparedness programs. These include Lock-Out /
Tag Out, Permit Entry Confined Space Entry, Emergency Response, and
others. Standard Operating Procedures have been developed to establish
uniformity and safety in the day to day operations of the refrigeration
system. Additionally, Marva Maid Dairy has developed and implemented a
comprehensive training program to insure the kno

wledge and skill levels of
its employees and operators is developed and maintained at a high level of
proficiency. The key element and foundation of the Marva Maid Dairy
safety and training programs is the Marva Maid Dairy Risk Management
and Prevention Program.

5.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

During the five year period preceding this report there has been one
release from covered processes that resulted in significant property
damage on site. This occurred when a forklift struck an ammonia liquid
transfer line, breaking the pipe. Approximately 1330 pounds of ammonia
were released and significant dairy product was contaminated and had to
be destroyed.

6.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

It is the intent of Marva Maid Dairy to prevent all foreseeable emergencies.
Emergencies are not completely preventable so this plan defines the
framework for an effective emergency response. The framework addresses
such issues as training, preparation, assignment of authority, and risk
assessment. It gives employees procedures to follow for effective and safe
actions during an emergency, including evacuation.
The Marva Maid Dairy emergency response program has specific
procedures for accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia as well as other
emergencies. We work in conjunction with the local Fire Department and
the Local Emergency Planning Committee to prepare for necessary
notification of all effected neighbors.

7.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Based on the completed Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for ammonia, a
list of action items to improve safety was developed and their status
monitored to ensure that implementation is accomplished.
